text: Family Member 1: And so like, now when he starts chemo or whatever and if he gets nauseous, I call M____? Doctor: Exactly. Yep. And you know, we'll make sure you have your prescription or whatever. Well, hopefully we'll have to give it to you so that, you know, when people run into trouble, it's always at 2 AM in the morning, right? Family Member 1: Right? Doctor: When you're like, “Uh oh, nowhere to go and no one to call.” So, first of all, you'll have that in your medicine cabinet. We'll make sure you have your nausea medication, because that's usually the thing that runs into trouble. You know, if you have diarrhea or constipation, that's over the counter that you can get, go to any 24 hour pharmacy for that. Family Member 1: Okay, yeah. Doctor: But things that are nausea medicines require prescriptions. Family Member 1: Do you do Zofran? Doctor: We do Zofran and we do Compazine. And then depending on the level of how much nausea you know. Family Member 1: Zofran works for me. I got pneumonia. Doctor: Well, you're right. And I think the important part here is that this is not a big nausea, type of chemo. There are some where you're like, “Okay, brace yourself, it's going to happen.” This is pretty mild. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It's actually called a mild emetogenic. So it just means it’s not gonna make you puke, but everybody's different.

text: Healthcare Professional 1: Oh. Doctor: G_? Healthcare Professional 1: He had progression on his bone scan and CAT scan. That’s what he might have gone through. Doctor: Oh, could be. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then we also have some chemotherapy trials which we potentially could consider if we were ready to do chemotherapy. Um, the um, trial, the trial in the cracks that we have, one is an immune therapy trial. Uh so right now when we get immune therapy, the reason that we use it for a lot of cancers, they haven’t worked so well by itself for prostate cancer. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So one thing we can look at is what if we give two immune therapies versus one. In an earlier study we did we saw more men that it worked in more men. So now we’re doing a bigger study. The down side of that is when we give two immune therapies the toxicity is much worse. So about half of the men I, I would estimate headed to the hospital with toxicity. Patient: Oh, really? Doctor: The main toxicity is really bad diarrhea. Because what these immune therapies are doing is sort of tipping the balance a little bit, trying to get the immune system to start seeing the cancer as foreign. Patient: Ahh. Doctor: But because the cancer is you, if you go too far, your immune system starts to see you as foreign, and we get colitis or pneumonitis, lung inflammation, appetite . So there’s, so it’s a, it’s a balance. It’s promising but the side effects, you know may be a little bit scary. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Uh that probably would also require you to have a certain monitor in your blood, and what that monitor is, uh, some men, particularly if they have been on a lot of hormone treatments, lowering treatments, the cancer evolves and adapts. It starts making this version of uh a receptor for the hormone. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So, I, I, I use this value of kind of a baseball and glove where testosterone is the baseball and the receptor is the glove.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
